content: Given a polynomial dynamical system, is it the law of mass action applied to some Petri net with rates?
My guess is yes (contrary to the claim! So my guess is probably wrong, but as an educational exercise I'll try to prove my guess tp see why...)
@Sam Tenka, it would help me parse this if you used Latex! 1+1=21 + 1 = 21+1=2
This is a very cool feature of Zulip imo :smiley:
@Sophie Libkind oh ah cool! I'll rewrite in LaTeX\LaTeXLATE​X shortly!

NOTE :
my original proof from tens of minutes ago had an (easy-to-fix) arithmetic error, but instead of fixing it in a minimal way, I chose to replace it by an essentially different and somewhat simpler construction.

SETUP:
Let XXX be a finite set of formal variables. The latter generate the ring R=R[X]R = \mathbb{R}[X]R=R[X]. A formal diffeq is an ∣X∣|X|∣X∣-tuplet (fx:x∈X)∈RX(f_x : x \in X) \in R^X(fx​:x∈X)∈RX of members of RRR; each formal diffeq determines an actual diffeq (first order with ∣X∣|X|∣X∣ equations): (Dx=fx(y:y∈X):x∈X)(D x = f_x(y : y\in X) : x\in X)(Dx=fx​(y:y∈X):x∈X). Here, DDD denotes differentiation-wrt-time.

Another structure we consider is that of a chemistry homework problem (CHP): a CHP is a member of M(R≥0×M(X)×M(X))M(\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \times M(X) \times M(X))M(R≥0​×M(X)×M(X)). Here, M:Set→SetM:\textsf{Set}\to\textsf{Set}M:Set→Set is the "finite multiset constructor". MMM sends a set to the set of finite multisets whose every member is in that set. Though MMM is a functor with great properties, we're introducing it merely to save ink. Of course, the terminal object in Set\textsf{Set}Set induces for each XXX a map weightX:M(X)→M(1)=N\text{weight}_X:M(X)\to M(1)=\mathbb{N}weightX​:M(X)→M(1)=N. Using this and pullbacks, it's not hard to make the good ol' "tell me the multiplicity in a given multiset of an element" function countX:M(X)×X→N\text{count}_X:M(X)\times X \to \mathbb{N}countX​:M(X)×X→N. Terminals and pullbacks are both limits, so it seems that counting is more "rightish/limity" than "leftish/colimity".

The point is that each CHP ccc induces an formal diffEQ as follows: for each x∈Xx\in Xx∈X we define fx=∑(r,lin,lout)∈c(∏y∈liny)⋅(−countX(lin,x)+countX(lout,x))f_x = \sum_{(r,l_{in},l_{out}) \in c} (\prod_{y \in l_{in}} y) \cdot (- \text{count}_X(l_{in}, x) + \text{count}_X(l_{out}, x))fx​=∑(r,lin​,lout​)∈c​(∏y∈lin​​y)⋅(−countX​(lin​,x)+countX​(lout​,x)).

Sam's CLAIM:
every formal diffEQ arises as above from some CHP.

PROOF (with a gap discussed at end):
Let's just construct ccc from (fx:x∈X)(f_x : x\in X)(fx​:x∈X).
Observing that the construction from CHPs to formal diffEQs sends disjoint unions to component-wise sums, it suffices to consider the case where one fxf_xfx​ is a monomial and the other fyf_yfy​'s are zero. Say that fx=s⋅∏y∈Lyf_x = s \cdot \prod_{y \in L} yfx​=s⋅∏y∈L​y, where s∈Rs \in \mathbb{R}s∈R and L∈M(X)L \in M(X)L∈M(X).

Well, if s∈R≥0s \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}s∈R≥0​ is non-negative, then we make the CHP c=[(s,L,∑y∈X(δ(y,x)+countX(L,y))⋅[y])]c = [(s, L, \sum_{y\in X} (\delta(y,x)+\text{count}_X(L,y)) \cdot [y])]c=[(s,L,∑y∈X​(δ(y,x)+countX​(L,y))⋅[y])]. Here, summing multisets just sums their multiplicities; multiplying a multiset by a natural number just multiplies all the multiplicities accordingly; and δ(y,x)\delta(y,x)δ(y,x) is one on the diagonal and zero elsewhere. One verifies by staring hard that ccc is a CHP and that it induces the desired formal diffEQ.

What if s=−∣s∣s=-|s|s=−∣s∣ is negative? Well, we make a CHP c′=[(∣s∣/countX(L,x),L,[])]c^\prime = [(|s|/\text{count}_X(L,x), L, [])]c′=[(∣s∣/countX​(L,x),L,[])]. This gives us the right behavior for DxD xDx, but it decreases the concentrations of the other species too much; to fix this, we just apply the non-negative case to add more elements into our CHP to cancel out those decreases. One verifies by staring hard that making ccc from c′c^\primec′ in this way induces the desired formal diffEQ --- EXCEPT that in the process of staring hard, one finds that c′c^\primec′ ain't always a well-defined CHP, since we might divide by zero!!!!!

Thus, QEND --- quod erat non demonstrandum.

REMARK:
the above proof works so long as the "diagonal counts" (countX(fx,x):x∈X)(\text{count}_X(f_x, x) : x\in X)(countX​(fx​,x):x∈X) are all non-zero (i.e. positive integers). Call a formal diffEQ for which this holds, everywhere loopy. Then

PROVEN CLAIM:
every everywhere loopy formal diffEQ arises from some chemistry homework problem!

(converse untrue)
Another useful Zulip tip: You can use the button that looks like :eye: to preview your message before you send it. :stuck_out_tongue:

The above considerations suggest this system:

Dx=−y,Dy=0D x = -y, D y = 0Dx=−y,Dy=0
or a cousin
Dx=−y,Dy=−xD x = -y, D y = -xDx=−y,Dy=−x

Can some invariant argument can show that one of these cannot come from a petri net with nonnegative rates?
I'm not sure!

Sam Tenka said:

The above considerations suggest this system:

Dx=−y,Dy=0D x = -y, D y = 0Dx=−y,Dy=0

or this cousin [...]

Can some invariant argument can show that one of these cannot come from a petri net with nonnegative rates?
I'm not sure!

This looks good. If a Petri net with rates gives the equation

ddtx=−y \frac{d}{dt} x = - y dtd​x=−y

the law of mass action says there must be a transition (at least one) whose input is just one y. In theory such a transition could have any number of x's and y's as output, but no such transition can make the concentration of x decrease, as this equation does.
This is not a rigorous proof but it's good enough for me right now.
